revision.text:
{{Infobox NRHP | name = Kendall Boiler and Tank Company Building | nrhp_type = cp | image = Kendall Boiler and Tank Company building.jpg | alt = | caption = The Kendall Boiler and Tank Company Building is part of the larger [[Blake and Knowles Steam Pump Company National Register District]]. | locmapin = Massachusetts | map_alt = | map_caption = | lat_degrees = 42 | lat_minutes = 21 | lat_seconds = 58 | lat_direction = N | long_degrees = 71 | long_minutes = 5 | long_seconds = 2 | long_direction = W | location = 275 Third Street, [[Cambridge, Massachusetts]] | built = | architect = | architecture = | added = June 13, 1997 | partof = Blake and Knowles Steam Pump Company National Register District | partof_refnum = 97000561 | governing_body = Private }} '''Kendall Boiler and Tank Company Building''' is a one story commercial edifice located on 275 Third Street in [[Kendall Square]], [[Cambridge, Massachusetts]]. The brick building was formerly owned by the Kendall Boiler and Tank Company and is part of the [[Blake and Knowles Steam Pump Company National Register District]], on the [[National Register of Historic Places]]. <ref>[http://www.worthingtonapt.com/history2.htm History2<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
In 1880 Mr. Edward Kendall founded the company to manufacture steam boilers. Kendall Boiler and Tank Company relocated to its present home in Chelmsford, MA in the 20th century. <ref>[http://kendallboiler.com/our-history/ Kendall Boiler and Tank Co., Inc. Boiler Repair Service<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
The building was restored by Pfeufer Richardson Architects to meet ADA standards for accessibility. There is 8,000 square feet of office space and an underground parking garage.<ref>[http://www.praarch.com/project.aspx?projectID=5 PRA - Pfeufer Richardson Architects P.C<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> In 2000 the building received a Cambridge Historical Commission Preservation Award. <ref>[http://www2.cambridgema.gov/Historic/awards.html Preservation Awards<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
The building was used by the [[Church of Latter Day Saints]] until 2010, when they moved to their new East Cambridge temple. <ref>[http://www.boston.com/news/local/articles_of_faith/2008/09/mormons_break_g.html Mormons begin new Cambridge building - Articles of Faith - Boston.com<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> In 2012 [[hack/reduce]], a nonprofit [[Big Data]] workspace founded by [[Christopher P. Lynch]] of [[Atlas Ventures]] and Frederic Lalonde of Hopper, opened its doors. <ref>[http://bostinno.com/2012/11/07/no-hacks-allowed-hackreduce-launches-thursday-to-help-boston-step-up-its-big-data-game/ hack/reduce: Boston Steps Up Its Big Data Game | BostInno<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
